issues.text: Whether, in a Special Leave to Appeal under article 136, it is open to the appellants to re-agitate questions of fact and disturb the findings of fact arrived at by the Courts below?

anchor.surface_text: In a Special Leave to Appeal under article 136, it is not open to the appellants to re-agitate questions of fact and ask the Court to disturb the findings of fact arrived at by the Courts below.

issues.text: Whether there was absence of mens rea necessary to establish under section 392 IPC?

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that there was absence of mens rea which it is necessary to establish under section 392. It is contended that the appellants honestly believed that they were taking the goods to a place within the State of Madhya Pradesh when they were caught in the mid-stream.

issues.text: Whether the appellants who had been prosecuted and acquitted under section 7 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act could be tried again under sections 392 and 332 IPC in view of section 403 CrPC?

anchor.surface_text: It was also contended that the appellants were already prosecuted for an offence under section 7 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act, 1946, for exporting the contraband goods and although they were convicted by the Magistrate they were acquitted on appeal by the Additional Sessions Judge, Sagar, on October 31, 1952.

arguments.claim: Sections 236 and 237 CrPC do not apply to bar retrial

anchor.surface_text: Neither section 236 which deals with a case where there is a doubt as to which offence has been companymitted number section 237 which entitles the Court to companyvict a person of an offence which he is shown to have companymitted although he was number charged with it, applies.

arguments.claim: Section 403(2) CrPC allows subsequent trial for distinct offence under ss.332/392 IPC

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  2  of section 403 in our opinion furnishes a companyplete answer to the companytention raised on behalf of the appellants. ... The appellants were number tried again for the same offence as companytemplated under section 403 1  but for a distinct offence as companytemplated by sub-section  2 .

arguments.court_reasoning: Offences distinct; required considering legality of seizure but focused on robbery and hurt to public servant

holdings.text: In a Special Leave to Appeal under article 136, it is not open to the appellants to re-agitate questions of fact and ask the Court to disturb the findings of fact arrived at by the Courts below. Those findings must therefore be accepted as binding.

anchor.surface_text: In a Special Leave to Appeal under article 136, it is not open to the appellants to re-agitate questions of fact and ask the Court to disturb the findings of fact arrived at by the Courts below. Those findings must therefore be accepted as binding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies settled practice that Supreme Court does not re-examine concurrent findings of fact in special leave petitions under Article 136 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: There was no absence of mens rea under section 392 IPC as the route chosen by the appellants led to Uttar Pradesh, negativing their claim of honest belief that goods were destined within Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: This conclusion is, however, clearly negatived by the finding that the route which the appellants had chosen was not the route which led to Baraitha or any other place within Madhya Pradesh State but actually led to Uttar Pradesh.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects mens rea defence based on binding factual finding that appellants chose route to another state, indicating knowledge of prohibited export.

holdings.text: Sections 236 and 237 CrPC do not apply to bar the trial under sections 332 and 392 IPC following acquittal under section 7 of the Essential Supplies Act.

anchor.surface_text: Neither section 236 which deals with a case where there is a doubt as to which offence has been committed nor section 237 which entitles the Court to convict a person of an offence which he is shown to have committed although he was not charged with it, applies.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes provisions: s.236 for doubt on offence, s.237 for conviction on uncharged offence shown committed; neither situation present here.

holdings.text: Sub-section 2 of section 403 CrPC permits subsequent trial for distinct offence under sections 332 and 392 IPC, which are distinct from the offence under section 7 Essential Supplies Act; appellants tried for distinct offence for which separate charge possible under s.235(1) CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 2 of section 403 in our opinion furnishes a complete answer to the contention raised on behalf of the appellants. ... The appellants were not tried again for the same offence as contemplated under section 403(1) but for a distinct offence as contemplated by sub-section 2.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.403(2) exception applies as offences distinct: prior trial on export prohibition; later on hurt to public servant and robbery of seized goods, requiring separate consideration of seizure legality and robbery/hurt elements.

holdings.text: There is no substance in the contentions raised by the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that there is no substance in this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative rejection of factual re-agitation, mens rea defence, and double jeopardy plea based on binding facts and statutory interpretation.

anchor.surface_text: Upon both these points the finding of the Courts below is companycurrent. We hold that there is numbersubstance in this companytention.

outcome.relief_summary: Findings of lower courts upheld on legality of seizure and commission of offences under sections 332 and 392 IPC; no substance in appellants' contentions
